intro: Astragalus candolleanus var. acuminatus, commonly known as the acuminated milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellow to reddish-purple flowers. The plant is adapted to harsh environments, featuring deep root systems that help it survive in dry conditions. Its flowers are typically arranged in racemes and are pollinated by insects, contributing to its ecological role in supporting local pollinator populations. The species is also valued in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
